ag consumer line...

What is freezer bum and how can it be prevented?

Freezer burn is dehydration or drying that occurs on the surface of a food product that was not wrapped properly before it was frozen. It is safe to eat, but the quality has deteriorated. The package must be free of air and sealed airtight in freezer wrap or an appropriate container to prevent this problem.

* * * 4:

Is it illegal for a service station to post a price on the sign out front for gas, then have a higher price on the pump? This happened to me twice last weekend when I stopped to get gas during a trip to South Georgia.

Yes, it is illegal to post one price on a sign and charge another at the pump. However, you should look at the prices carefully. For example, the lower price may be for self-service gas and the higher one for full-service. Or one price may be for cash and another for credit card purchases. This is legal, but the qualify ing statements must be posted along with the prices.

Ifyou have problems or questions concerning products or services regulated by the Georgia Department of Agriculture, write: Consumer Services, Room 226, Agriculture Building, 19 M.L. King, Jr. Dr., Atlanta, Georgia 30334-4201, or call toll-free, 1-800282-5852 or in metro Atlanta, 656-3645.

Notice of Auction of Equine

Pursuant to Section 4-13-7 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (Human Care for Equines Act), the Georgia Department of Agriculture will receive sealed bids on the follow ing equine as grade horses, to wit:

Sorrel QHX Gld Approx. 11 yrs. Bay QHX Gld Approx. 15 yrs. The said equine may be inspected at the Department of Agriculture's Equine Impounded Facility located in DeKalb County, Georgia, from 12 noon until 6 p.m. on Friday, May 26, and Friday June 2, 1995. For directions to location, call (404) 656-3713. Sealed bids only will be received on the equine. Bids should be in individual sealed envelopes with the description of the animal indi cated on the outside of the envelope. Bids must be in writing and should include the description of animal; cash bid offer; the name, address and day time telephone number of person offering the bid; and a statement that it is being made subject to the terms of this notice. All sealed bids should be sent or delivered to: Mr. Robert Haralson Equine Division, Room 113" Georgia Department of Agriculture Capitol Square 19 Martin Luther King Jr. Drive Atlanta, GA 30334 All bids must be received by 9 a.m., Monday, June 5, 1995. Said equine are being sold as impounded ani mals belonging to Keith Santana under the author ity of Chapter 13 of Title 4 of O.C.G.A. (Humane Care for Equines Act). No representation is made regarding any registration or possible registration of said equine nor of the physical condition of said equine. Any documentation in possession of the Department of Agriculture regarding registration, physical condition or past veterinary treatment of said equine is available upon request; however, not withstanding the availability of such docu mentation, or lack thereof, or verbal information given to the Department, said sale is for the equine on an "as is" basis without any representation regarding registration, physical condition or acceptable use of the animal. The successful bid der will be notified by telephone on Monday, June 5, 1995, and must be prepared to tender the price by cashiers check and move the animal from the impounded facility by 12 noon on Tuesday, June 6, 1995.

Summer Equine Edition

Scheduled for July 5

The Farmers and Consumers Market Bulletin special summer equine edition is scheduled for July 5. This issue will include notices for horse shows in July, August and September, as well as listings of horses at stud, boarding facilities and ads for miscellaneous equine equipment and supplies. A 30-word limit will be observed for these notices. Deadline for the edition is June 21.

Notices included in the "Equine for Sale" category and "At Stud" column must be accompanied by a copy of a valid, negative Coggins test (made within the past 12 months); otherwise, they will not be published.

In addition, the Georgia Animal Protection Act requires boarding and breeding facilities to be licensed. Current license number must be submitted with notices for "At Stud" and "Boarding Facilities." Notices submitted without this information will not be published. For licensing information and applica tions, call 404-656-3713.

Remember Safety Rules With Yard, Garden Tools

Garden tractors, tillers and other out door power equipment have become essential in preparing and maintaining lawns and gardens. Although these tools can help save time and ease lawn and gar den chores, they can be dangerous if not used properly.

To ensure you complete your lawn and garden chores safely, follow these guide lines provided by Dr. Bobby Tyson, agri cultural engineer with the University of Georgia Extension Service:

* read the manual. Understand the controls and all of the rules, especially the safety rules. Never remove the safety guards from your equipment.

* children and pets shouldn't be in the area when you start the engine. Kids don't belong on a riding mower or garden tractor, especially as passengers. The chances of their falling off are too great and too common a cause of accidents.

* if the equipment clogs or the engine makes a funny noise, stop immediately. Turn off the engine, disconnect the spark plug wire or electric plug and make sure all moving parts have stopped before

making adjustments or repairs. * when using a walk-behind power

mower, mow slopes sideways. It's usual ly faster and always safer. You can keep the lawn mower under control and avoid the chance of slipping on the way down or having the mower rumble down on you on the way up.

* riding mowers should be ridden up and down slopes. The riding mower is more stable this way, and you avoid the possibility that it will tip over sideways.

Many safety factors have been built into power tools for lawn and garden. Most are double-insulated to prevent electrical shock. They also have chain guards, safety tips, power cord protectors, shields, etc.

Most hand tools, however, don't have these safety devices because they move slowly and aren't self-powered.

Here are some safety precautions to take when using hand tools in the lawn and garden;

* wear safety goggles when sharpen ing tools, especially when grinding edges
